Award.AwardTitle: Harnessing Redox-Active Ligands and Cofactors to Facilitate Multi-electron Reactivity
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Alan Heyduk of the Department of Chemistry at the University of California, Irvine to develop new molecular catalysts for splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen. The utilization of intermittent alternative energy sources such as wind and solar requires that efficient conversion strategies be developed to generate chemical fuels. Water-splitting to afford hydrogen and oxygen is an attractive energy-storing reaction for this goal, and for widespread applicability, these catalysts must be made from inexpensive and earth-abundant elements. This project is also providing avenues for the training of students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels and includes strong representation from groups that are historically underrepresented in the sciences.

Professor Heyduk is developing new tridentate, redox active ligands that can be shuttled among three oxidation states while bound to a metal, as a way to introduce multi-electron redox functionality to the metal complex. The PI is exploring the use of these complexes in the catalysis of important multi-electron reactions, such as water oxidation and proton reduction. The ultimate goal of the project is to generate molecular electrocatalysts for both halves of the water-splitting reaction and based upon earth abundant first row transition metals. The development of new molecular catalysts for the electrochemical reduction of protons to hydrogen and the electrochemical oxidation of water to oxygen provide insights into the mechanistic and kinetic barriers to efficient water splitting. For widespread applicability, these catalysts must be made from inexpensive and earth-abundant elements, where the factors governing multi-electron reactivity are yet to be elucidated. Success in this endeavor will impact alternative energy strategies by providing new avenues for the conversion of transient energy sources into storable, portable, chemical fuels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research project entitled, "Harnessing Redox-Active Ligands and Cofactors to Facilitate Multi-electron Reactivity," has been completed by the PI Prof. Alan Heyduk and his research team at the University of California, Irvine. The project had two research thrusts, the first aimed at developing multi-electron oxidation reactions using monometallic chromium complexes and the second aimed at developing multi-electron reduction reactions using hetero-multimetallic cluster complexes. The group also organizes and hosts the SoCal Undergraduate Research Symposium each summer.

In support of the first thrust, graduate student researchers developed a new family of chromium complexes containing a tridentate redox-active [ONO] ligand platform derived from bis-(3,5-di-tert-butyl-2-phenol)amine. The coordination environment of the complexes also included a neutral bidentate bipyridine donor ligand, which was intended to work in concert with [ONO] ligand to occupy five binding site of an octahedron, leaving one coordination site open for the generation of strong oxidants. These [ONO]Cr(bpy)X complexes were studied under strongly oxidizing conditions with the goal of generating high-valent chromium-oxo intermediates capable of oxygen-atom transfer reactivity. While the ultimate goal of O–O bond formation was not realized, O-atom transfer to a variety of substrates including amines, sulfides, and phosphines was observed. Attempts to study the mechanism of these O-atom transfer reactions revealed complicated kinetic profiles and limited turnover frequencies that were not amenible to detailed study.

For the second thrust, graduate students developed a new class of hetero-multimetallic cluster complexes based upon a redox-active metalliligand, M[SNS]2. These new cluster complexes were developed as catalysts for multi-electron reduction reactions including the electrochemical production of hydrogen gas from acidic solutions. Mechanistic studies on the most active catalyst, a tungsten-nickel hetero-bimetallic complex, suggested that the active site for proton reduction the thiolate donors of the [SNS] ligand platform, with the tungsten and nickel centers serving as structural elements to tune the overall electronics of the catalyst. 

In related synthetic work, hetero-trimetallic complexes were prepared and the structural and electronic properties were elucidated. These complexes proved to be good model complexes for metal chalcogenides that are of interest as semiconductor materials. The hetero-trimetallic systems developed in this program showed a rich redox-chemistry and the ability to stabilize mixed-valence electron configurations. A key aspect of stabilizing the redox chemistry was structural flexibility within the hetero-trimetallic core, which allows for the formation and cleavage of metal-metal bonds to modulate the storage of electrons within the cluster.

In addition to the research outcomes cited above, the PIs team organized and hosted the annual SoCal Undergraduate Research Symposium each summer on the UC Irvine campus. This one-day symposium attracts over 100 students each year from colleges and universities across southern California. The attendees present their own research results, listen to research talks from Chemistry Department faculty, and most importantly attend seminars and workshops aimed at teaching them how to apply to graduate school and for NSF fellowships to support their advanced studies. A majority of these students come from primarily undergraduate institutions and a large fraction also belong to groups that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 04/08/2020
Modified by: Alan F Heyduk
